title: 111_hr6525
content: The Act is titled the "Former Bennett Freeze Area Development Act" and defines terms such as ONHIR, Secretary, and Trust Fund. It also addresses the transition of ONHIR. Upon request by the Navajo Nation or Hopi Tribe, the Commissioner of the Office of Navajo and Hopi Indian Relocation can enter into self-determination contracts for programs and services, including administrative functions that support service delivery to Indians. The Commissioner of the Office of Navajo and Hopi Indian Relocation can contract out administrative functions regardless of the organizational level, with regulations mirroring the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act and recognizing the agency's independent status. SEC. 4. FORMER BENNETT FREEZE AREA REHABILITATION TRUST FUND. Establishment of the Former Bennett Freeze Area Rehabilitation Trust Fund in the Treasury of the United States, with funds appropriated for its use. The Secretary serves as trustee and is responsible for fund investment. Funds will be transferred to the Navajo-Hopi Land Commission Office upon approval of a plan for their use. The Freeze Area Rehabilitation Trust Fund is available to the Navajo Nation for economic, housing, infrastructure, health, educational, and social improvements in communities affected by the former Bennett Freeze. The Trust Fund consists of set-asides from appropriations for Indian Programs and the Indian Housing Block Grant Program. The Rehabilitation Trust Fund, funded by appropriations for the Rural Development Program and other sources, will terminate when its goals are met, with remaining funds transferred to the Treasury. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2011 through 2025. The Rehabilitation Trust Fund will terminate when goals are met, with remaining funds transferred to the Treasury. Appropriations authorized for fiscal years 2011 through 2025. SEC. 5. MISCELLANEOUS. The amendment expands ONHIR authority to implement a rehabilitation program addressing the effects of the 'Bennett Freeze' on the Navajo Reservation, focusing on housing, infrastructure, and economic development. Appropriations are authorized for this program. The Navajo Nation has the right to negotiate and approve an Accommodation Agreement with the Hopi Tribe for any Navajo head of household residing on Hopi Partitioned Land. The Navajo-Hopi Land Dispute Settlement Act of 1996 is amended to include a new section 13 regarding the relinquishment of Accommodation Agreement and eligibility for relocation benefits on Hopi Partitioned Land. Section 13 of the Navajo-Hopi Land Dispute Settlement Act of 1996 addresses the relinquishment of Accommodation Agreement and eligibility for relocation benefits on Hopi Partitioned Land. The Navajo-Hopi Land Dispute Settlement Act allows Navajo families to relinquish Accommodation Agreements and receive full relocation benefits, including housing and counseling. Appropriations are authorized for the programs outlined in the amendments. The Navajo-Hopi Land Dispute Settlement Act authorizes appropriations for programs on the Navajo and Hopi Reservations, in addition to existing funds for Indian assistance.
